Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Appearing for the Government, Myriam Fernandez, for defendant Rachel Bril and PTS, Nancy Mendez. Defendant is present and is (U/C).Arraignment and Detention Hearing as to Wilfredo Diaz- Vargas (6) Count 1,2,3,4,5,6,7 held on 6/18/2008. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment and enters a plea of not guilty as to all counts. The parties are granted 5 days for discovery and 10 days thereafter to file any motions. The case is referred to Judge Dominguez for trial setting. As to Detention, defense counsel states that at this time it has nothing to add but after speaking with defendant's wife will look into this matter and most probably will file a motion to reope bail. Counsel for the Government is heard and concurs with the pretrial recommendation. The Court states that taking into account the statements made by counsel and after reviewing the pretrial report, the Court finds that defendant is a risk of flight and a danger to the community and orders that defendant be detain pending trial. (mn) (Entered: 06/18/2008)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Appearing for the Government, Myriam Fernandez and for defendant, Victoria Ferrer. Defendant is present in Court and is (U/C).Arraignment and Detention Hearing as to Jose A. Laboy-Crespo (87) Count 1,2,3,4,5,7 held on 6/18/2008. Defendant waived the reading of the indictment and enters a plea of not guilty as to all counts. The parties are granted 5 days for discovery and 10 days thereafter to file any motions. The case is referred to Judge Dominguez for trial setting. As to detention hearing, defense counsel is heard and states that she is in agreement with the pretrial report, except for the issue of working, which defendant was working in Walmart. She further is heard as to this. Counsel for the Government is heard and states that she does not object to the fashioning of the conditions of release, specifically that defendant should be advised that he should not visit the area where the drug was distributed. The Cour6 after hearing counsels statements and taking into account the pretrial report, sets bail in the amount of $20,000.00 of which $10,000.00 are cash or secured and the remaining unsecured. Defendant shall work at Walmart or seek to continue to be employed. Curfew from 7:00 PM to 4:30 A.M. at residence. Defendant shall refrain from going to those places alleged in the indictment. Standard conditions of release shall apply. (Court Reporter FTR.) (mn) (Entered: 06/18/2008)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez:Arraignment as to Alfred Rivera-Torres (35) Counts 1,2,3,4,5,7 and Bail Hearing held on 6/19/2008.Present were AUSA Jose Capo and defense counsel Miriam Ramos. Defendant waived the reading of the indictment. PONG entered. Defendant remains under custody. Defense counsel is granted five (5) for discovery and ten (10) days thereafter to file all motions. The case is referred to Judge Dominguez for trial setting. As to Bail, defense counsel informed defendant is not a drug user, wants to continue education, has been working with his father, and has no prior convictions. The Government requested defendant be detained pending trial for being risk of flight and danger to the community. After listening the parties, taken in consideration the recommendations of the Pretrial Report and the seriousness of the charges, the Court finds defendant to be a danger to community and ordered to be detained pending trial. Defense counsel requested the Pretrial Report be amended as to the effect that defendant surrendered to the Police office in Ponce. The Court requested Pretrial Services take note that this defendant surrendered. (PTO Nancy Mendez, CI Hilda Gutierrez and CD Elba Rivas) (Court Reporter FTR.) (er) (Entered: 06/20/2008)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez:Arraignment as to Luis Archeval (58) Count 1,2,3,4,5,7 and Bail Hearing held on 6/19/2008. ORDER as to Miguel Caraballo. Defendant's motion for reconsideration of the order of detention pending trial is DENIED. Although the defendant presented some evidence during the de novo bail hearing to rebut the statutory presumption of risk of flight, I reaffirm my previous finding that the defendant is a danger to the community: the defendant has a lengthy criminal record, with convictions for murder, weapons, robbery, controlled substances, and escape, and the facts of the present case arose while he was on parole. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Daniel R. DOMNGUEZ: Motion Hearing as to Israel Torres-Maldonado held on 1/8/2009, as to Pro Se Motion 939 filed by Israel Torres-Maldonado (48). Present for the United States, Myriam Fernandez. For the defendant, Jose Suarez Santa. The defendant was present in court, and was assisted by the official court interpreter, Marie Hernandez. The Court heard the parties. The defendant insisted that counsel Suarez Santa be relieved as his legal representation. The petition made by the defendant was denied. Then, the Court heard counsel Suarez Santa, who advised the Court that this defendant has been disrespectful towards him, hence counsel Suarez requested to be relieved as counsel for this defendant. That petition made by counsel Suarez was granted by the Court. Counsel Jorge L. Armenteros- Chervoni was appointed to represent defendant Israel Torres Maldonado under the Criminal Justice Act. The defendant was strongly admonished by the Court for his behavior against counsel Suarez, and was advised that any further misconduct act against his attorney, an order to the BOP that this defendant be placed at the "hole" at MDC Guaynabo. Counsel Suarez Santa shall provide the discovery to counsel Armenteros forthwith. (Court Reporter Barbara Dachman.)(Court Interpreter Marie Hernandez.)Hearing set for 04:00.Hearing held at 05:30.Hearing ended at 05:52. (om) (Entered: 01/12/2009)

ORDER denying 1174 Motion for Bill of Particulars as to Carlos G. Santiago-Torres (109). Defendant claims the indictment contains no specific allegations as to the dates, locations and manner in which he allegedly participated in the conspiracy. The indictment, however, provides such information with a reasonable degree of detail. As to the time span and locations of the alleged conspiracy, see Docket 3 on pages 8, 22, 25, 29, 32 at the beginning of each count. As to locations, see also Docket 3 at page12 under the subtitle Object of the Conspiracy. As to manner, see Docket 3 at pages 12-13 under the subtitle Manner and Means; see also Docket 3 at page 21 regarding the description of what allegedly defendant Carlos Santiago Torres did as a drug processor/facilitator on behalf of the conspiracy. Signed by US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez on 4/8/09. (Lopez, Marcos) (Entered: 04/08/2009)

ORDER denying 1258 Motion for Bill of Particulars as to Hector A. Correa-Martinez (74). The motion for bill of particulars, filed nearly ten months after defendant's arraignment, is untimely pursuant to Fed. R. Crim. P. 7(f), and defendant has provided no reason why it should be considered at this time. Even if the motion were considered timely, I find that the indictment adequately informs the defendant of the charges against him, insofar as it sets forth the time frame of the alleged conspiracy and other charges, identifies the co-defendants, identifies the location of the alleged drug points, identifies the alleged controlled substances involved, and identifies the defendant's alleged role in the conspiracy. Finally, defendant is not prevented from notifying the government of any alibi he might have in relation to any time periods during which the defendant allegedly was detained and/or incapacitated.Signed by US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin on April 13, 2009. (McGiverin, Bruce) (Entered: 04/13/2009)

***SELECTED PARTIES***PLEA SUPPLEMENT as to Manuel De-Jesus-Rios (77) (jm) (Entered: 04/13/2009)

ORDER denying 1397 Motion for Bill of Particulars as to William Santiago-Rivera (49) An almost identical motion by a co-defendant was denied by another Magistrate Judge upon a separate referral. For the purpose of consistency in discovery rulings, as well as for defendant Santiago-Rivera not presenting any grounds different to the ones raised by the co-defendant, the previous ruling denying the bill of particulars is hereby reiterated in that: the ten month delay since the date of arraignment would make this request to be untimely under Fed.R.Crim.P. 7(f); there is no reason for further consideration of the issue at this time; the indictment adequately informs the defendants of the charges, the location of the alleged drug points, and the controlled substances therein charged, even indicating each defendant's role in the conspiracy. Defendant Santiago-Rivera may still raise any alibi defense for the time periods where counsel states he could had been detained and/or incapacitated. Signed by US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive on 4/13/2009. (IM) (Entered: 04/13/2009)

Present were AUSA Myriam Fernandez and Mr. Jorge Vega-Pacheco. Mr. Vega argued that a month has elapsed since the filing of the motion and that the Government has not responded to the same, therefore it should be granted as unopposed. He also presented defendant's arguments as to the plea agreement. AUSA Fernandez stated the Government's position. The Court urged the parties to meet and discuss these issues, and requested that AUSA Jose Capo be present at the next hearing so that a resolution can be found as to this issue. The parties are to agree on a date this week in which the Court can hold the hearing and have Mr. Capo present, and inform the Court as to said date so that the hearing can be scheduled. ORDER as to Motion notifying potential conflict of calendar between the end of trial in Cr. 08-204 (DRD) and the start of trial in Crim. No. 06-299 (CCC), DE 2382 filed by Miguel Caraballo (14). Having examined Judge Cerezo's order at DE 1079 in Cr. 06-299 (CCC), the Court agrees that pursuant to Local Rule 3.2(f) the case before Judge Cerezo is older, and involves more defendants that have been in custody for a larger period of time than co-defendant in this case, Miguel Caraballo. The Court therefore vacates the jury trial set for October 19, 2009. As soon as counsel Matos finishes with the case before Judge Cerezo, shall notify this court. A status/trial setting conference will be set taking into consideration the Court's calendar, counsel Matos calendar, and pursuant to U.S. v. Santiago Becerril, 130 F.3d 11, 19 (1st Cir. 1997). IT IS SO ORDERED. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 10/13/2009. (om) (Entered: 10/13/2009)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez- Rive:Evidentiary Hearing as to Jose L. Torres-Pacheco held on 10/20/2009. Present were AUSA Myriam Fernandez and Mr. Thomas Lincoln. Mr. Lincoln stated for the record that he was not in agreement with defendant's pro se motion, but that if those were dft's wishes, he would abide by them. The Court addressed defendant explaining the consequences of changing attorney at this stage of the proceedings as well as other concerns the defendant had. Defendant was heard by the Court and given some time to speak with his attorney in order to solve the possible problem. After a short break, defendant stated for the record that he didn't want to have a new attorney appointed, but that he needed medical attention due to some injuries he had sustained while at MDC. Mr. Lincoln stated to the Court all of defendant's concerns and the Court ordered that Mr. Matos, legal adviser for MDC, be contacted as to this so that he could provide an answer to the Court. (Court Reporter -FTR.)(Court Interpreter -Felix Toledo.) (yr) (Entered: 10/29/2009)

Present were AUSA Mario Torres, and Jose R. Gaztambide. The defendant was present in court. Parties presented their respective positions. Reply to motion for withdrawal of guilty plea and request for withdrawal of counsel, DE 2430 was granted by the Court. Prose motions 2297 , 2318 , 2423 were denied. Present for this hearing were AUSA Mario Torres, and Gabriel Hernandez. The defendant was present in Court. The Court heard the parties. The Court determined that defendant's motions are insufficient as a matter of law. New counsel will be appointed at random pursuant to the CJA. Newly appointed counsel shall examine a letter sent by the defendant to the United States. Counsel Hernandez was relieved to continue representing this defendant. ORDER adopting Report and Recommendation re 2401 Report and Recommendation as to Mariano G. Alfaro-Cintron (102). The records shows that the Report and Recommendations is unopposed. Hence, the Court needs only satisfy itself that there is no plain error on the face of the record in order to accept an unopposed Report and Recommendation. See Douglass v United Servs. Auto, Assn, 79 F.3d 1415 (5th Cir. 1996); Nogueras-Cartagena v. United States, 172 F. Supp. 2d 296, 305 (D.P.R. 2001); Garcia v. I.N.S., 733 F. Supp. 1554 (M.D.Pa. 1990). After having reviewed the Report and Recommendation, the Court finds no plain error in the findings made by the Magistrate Judge Lopez, as the findings of fact and the conclusions of law, are well supported on the record and applicable law. Hence, the Court hereby adopts in toto the Report and Recommendation of the Magistrate Judge Lopez(Docket No. 2401). The Motion to withdraw as counsel (Docket No. 2108) is moot. IT IS SO ORDERED.Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 12/4/2009. (JAM) (Entered: 12/04/2009)

Munute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Arraignment as to Luis A. Picart-Alvarez (41) Count 1,2,3,4,5,7 held on 12/16/2009. Present AUSA Myriam Fernandez, Atty. Jose A. Figueroa-Santaella, and USPO Evelyn Jimenez. Defendant was found competent to understand the proceedings and waived the reading of the indictment. PONG entered as to all counts charged in the indictment. Case referred to Judge Dominguez for trial schedule. As to bail, defense counsel stated that at this time he had nothing to rebut the Pretrial Services Report and reserves the right to reopen the hearing. The Court granted government's motion for detention and ordered defendant detained without bail. Order to be issued. Defense counsel stated for the record that defendant uses eyeglasses and USMS have the custody of them and that he cannot read or see without them. Defense counsel requested that defendant be allowed to use his eyeglasses. The Court instructed Courtroomdeputy to send MDC a Notice informing that defendant through his attorney expressed the issue that he needed his eyeglasses. The Court ordered that defendant be allowed to use his eyeglasses in occasions when he meets with attorney to review videos and evidence regarding discovery of his case. Government is granted until 12/18/2009 at noon to file an informative motion presenting evidence regarding the matter of the eyeglasses. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Daniel R. Dominguez:Status Conference as to Miguel Caraballo, Jose L. Velazquez-Maldonado, Abraham R. Cardona-Padilla, Jean C. Rivera-Mercado, Ramon Rosado-Martinez held on 1/19/2010. After the change of plea hearings held today as to co-defendants Medina-Padilla (10), Cirino-Navarro (18), Rivera-Rivera (36), Quinones-Rivera (38), and Gonzalez-Jorge (39) the Court held a status conference with the pending defendants set for jury trial. The United States requested that more defendants be added. Counsel for co-defendants opposed. The Court after hearing arguments decided to excused the jury panel until next Monday, January 25, 2010 at 9:30 a.m. The Court reminded the parties, that at the last pretrial conference, was decided to select the jury today, and then proceedings will continue on January 25, 2010 for Preliminary Instructions, opening statements and the presentation of evidence since several counsel were granted additional time in order to be prepared for trial. Hence, the panel was excused until January 25, 2010 at 9:30 a.m. The Court will issue an order as to co-defendants Ramil Joel Quinones-Rivera (66) represented by Juan Nieves Cassas, Javier Maldonado-Cruz (72) represented by by Juan Alvarez Cobian, Reina Lee Mercado (78) represented by Jose R. Olmo, Jose A. Laboy- Crespo (87) represented by Victoria Ferrer, Jonathan Alvarado-Perez (91) represented by Ramon Garay, Edward Gutierrez-Lugo (95) represented by Robert Millan, Eduardo Colondres-Ramos (97) represented by Raymond Sanchez, Felix A. Gaston-Santiago (100) represented by Marie L. Cortes, Mariano G. Alfaro-Cintron (102) represented by Carlos Calderon, and Jose L. Castillo-Torres (104) represented by Jorge Gerena to attend a Pretrial Conference on January 21, 2010 at 1:00 p.m. On this date, seven (7) defendant will be added for jury trial. Counsel Chaves for co-defendant Rivera-Mercado (27) requested to be excused to attend jury trial. Petition was denied. Counsel Matos for Miguel Caraballo requested that be allowed to join co-defendant's Proposed Voir Dire questions filed at DE 2814. Petition was granted. In addition, counsel Matos requested a court order that daily transcripts and rough draft be provided to the defendants pursuant the CJA. The request was granted. Hence, the previous order issue for co-defendant Medina-Padilla was vacated, and now applies to co-defendant Miguel Caraballo (14). The Court Reporter shall provide daily transcripts and a rough draft to counsel Matos to be paid pursuant the CJA. Copies may be provided to co-counsel. Pretrial Conference set for 1/21/2010 01:00 PM. (Court Reporter Donna W. Dratwa.) (Court Interpreter Not Used.)Hearing held at 01:50.Hearing ended at 02:20. (om) (Entered: 01/22/2010)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Daniel R. Dominguez:Sentencing held on 3/29/2010 for Gabriel Rivera-Nieves (33). Statements in support of mitigation of punishment are heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution heard. Court finds that the defendant's CHC is over-represented. Court sentences defendant accordingly to the adjusted CHC. Count(s) 1, Term of imprisonment: One hundred and twenty-one (121) months. SRT of ten (10) years. No fine. SMA of $100.00.; Count(s) 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 are dismissed. No fine. Time served since 6/15/2008 is to be credited. Defense counsel states for the record that the defendant will not appeal his sentence. (Court Reporter Yvette Richardson.)(Court Interpreter Marie Hernandez.) Hearing set for 2:00. p.m. Hearing held at 3:40 p.m. Hearing ended at 4:40 p.m. (sr) Present: AUSA Myriam Fernandez and defense counsel Rafael Anglada. Defendant didn't require the services of the court interpreter, however, the interpreter's services were provided to defendant's relatives. USPO Victor Carlo also present. (Entered: 03/30/2010)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Chief Mag. Judge Justo Arenas: Change of Plea Hearing as to Richard Medina-Padilla held on 4/13/2010. AUSA Michael Bagge and defense counsel Laura Maldonado were present. Defendant was present in court and under custody. Consent was approved, filed and made part of the record. The defendant was found competent to plea. The Magistrate Judge will recommend to the Court that the Plea of Guilty be accepted as to Count One (1) of the Indictment. At the time of sentencing, the Government will request the dismissal of the remaining counts. The defendant is to remain under custody. A report and recommendation will be issued. The Court ordered the preparation of a presentence report. Sentence will be set at a later date. (Court Reporter FTR/bg, CD: Brenda Gonzalez.) (Court Interpreter Edna Brayfield.) Hearing set for 02:00. Hearing held at 02:20. Hearing ended at 02:39. (br) (Entered: 04/13/2010)

ORDER as to Jonathan Alindato-Perez (24), Ramon Rosado-Martinez (32)Motion to compel disclosure of co-conspirator statements, DE 3739 , granting 3757 , and Emergency Request for reconsideration, DE 3757 . Defendants request of co- conspirator statements is denied. A Co-conspirator statement is merely statements made by a witness which are exceptions to hearsay because the statements have a degree of reliability. These are merely statements by witnesses which are inadmissible by rule, Fed.R. 801(d)(2)(E). IT IS SO ORDERED. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 4/26/2010. (om) (Entered: 04/26/2010)

ORDER as to Luis D. Moreno-Almodovar re 3660 Notice of Appeal - Final Judgment filed by Luis D. Moreno-Almodovar. Out of abundance of caution, the defendant's Motion to Appeal is granted, notwithstanding that the defendant was represented by counsel at the sentencing hearing, and the Court advised the defendant that he had 30 days to appeal from the date of the sentencing hearing. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Daniel R. Dominguez:Sentencing held on 8/27/2010 for Israel Torres-Maldonado (48). Defendant is placed under oath and the motion filed at Docket No. 3959 is addressed. Government's proffer as to the version of facts is heard. The defendant reiterates his guilty plea of guilty pursuant to the terms within the plea agreement filed at Docket No. 3653. The Court reinstates the plea of guilty and grants the three (3) points for acceptance of responsibility. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment are heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution heard. Count(s) 1, Term of imprisonment: Ninety-six (96) months. SRT of eight (8) years. No fine. SMA of $100.00.; Count(s) 2, 3, 4, 5, 7, Dismissed. Defense counsel moves for reconsideration. Reconsideration is DENIED. However, within the next five (5) days, the defense is to file motion clarifying the charges and the sentence(s) imposed at state level. (Court Reporter Yvette Richardson.)(Court Interpreter Marie Hernandez) Hearing set for 9:30 a.m. Hearing held at 10:30 a.m. Hearing ended at 11:40 a.m. (sr) Present: AUSA Jose Capo and defense counsel Jorge Armenteros. Defendant only used the services of the Court Interpreter for purposes of his allocution. USPO Joan Vazquez also present. (Entered: 08/27/2010)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Daniel R. Dominguez:Motion Hearing as to Juan A. Ruiz-Gonzalez held on 9/23/2010 re 2549 First MOTION for Reconsideration AND OR CORRECTION OF SENTENCE. Present were AUSA Jose Capo, and for the defendant Jose Romo Matienzo. Defendant was present in court assisted by the official court interpreter. Parties presented their respective arguments. The Court after having heard the parties, denied the motion filed at DE 2549 . The Court ordered that the defendant be sent forthwith to the institution in which was designated, FCI Miami in order that the 500 hours drug residential program be provided to him. Finally, counsel Romo Matienzo requested that a voucher be prepared in accordance with the services rendered for the preparation and participation of today's proceedings. Petition was granted. Voucher shall be prepared by the person designated by Clerk of the Court. ORDER granting 4349 Motion to Quash as to Giovannie A. Negron-Rivera (26). The Motion to Quash is granted, as the documents request made by the Hon. Carmen L. Otero Ferreiras of the Puerto Rico Superior Court, Ponce District, fails to comply with the proper procedure, to wit: 28 C.F.R. sec. 16.21, et seq. AUSA Fidel Sevillano shall notify a copy of the Motion to Quash, as well as a copy of this Order to the following parties, in addition to the parties already notified: (a) the Secretary of the Puerto Rico Department of Justice; (b) the Federal Litigation Division of the Puerto Rico Department of Justice; and (c) the Puerto Rico District Attorney for the District of Ponce. AUSA Sevillano shall file a Certificate of Service or an Informative Motion within five days, after notice of this Order is given to the corresponding parties. IT IS SO ORDERED. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 2/22/2011. (JAM) (Entered: 02/22/2011)

ORDER denying 4442 Third Motion Requesting Order to Correct/amend the judgment as to Christopher Figueroa-Ortiz (84). This motion is DENIED. This is a similar motion as filed at DE 3337 and 3599, except the last paragraph. Judgment was amended as requested, and after reviewing the record, drug treatment was ordered to be provided pursuant to the information contained in the pre-sentence report. Now, counsel for the defendant is mistaken the record. As to this particular defendant, and most all defendants in this case, maximum drug treatment was recommended and/or ordered  pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Sec, 3553(a)(2)(d) to benefit the defendant. Hence, motion is DENIED. IT IS SO ORDERED. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 7/28/2011. (om) (Entered: 07/28/2011)

BY ORDER OF THE COURT, and in view of the stipulation entered into by the parties on December 20, 2011 (Docket No. 4645), the sentence of Wilfredo Diaz Vargas is modified in accordance with the provisions of 18 U.S.C. §3582(c)(2) and U.S.S.G. §1B1.10(c), Amendment 706 of the United States Sentencing Commission Guidelines. In  view of the court having approved the stipulation that a sentence of 121 months imprisonment is appropriate, and that no hearing is required to modify the sentence, the Clerk is directed to enter an amended judgment imposing a sentence of 121 months of imprisonment. ORDER as to Mariano G. Alfaro-Cintron re 4821 Letter sent by BOP TO JUDGE DOMINGUEZ. The United States, in this case AUSA Jose A. Capo, and counsel for the defendant, Carlos Calderon Garnier shall reply to the letter dated February 15, 2012 requesting the Court, retroactive designation. The United States and counsel for the defendant are ordered to express their position as to whether or not co-defendant Mariano G. Alfaro Cintron should be "retroactively designated". The Court provides AUSA Capo and counsel Calderon Garnier the following facts. 1. The Defendant was originally sentenced to 60 months. The defendant was brought to the jurisdiction of this court on June 16, 2008, see DE 129 . 2. Should the defendant be authorized for 85% credit, he should be serving around 51 months time of service which would be ending around September 2012. 3. Defendant is to be released from custody on or about September 28, 2012, if retroactive designation is allowed by the Court. The defendant has however been under state custody as the primary jurisdiction. The letter by the BOP does not state how much of the time since sentencing, the defendant has served in state custody. The Court grants both parties twenty (20) days to express their position. No extensions shall be granted. Counsel for the defendant shall be granted a new designation under the CJA. The U.S. Probation Officer shall advise the Court as to circumstances and locations of the crime as to the alleged weapons violation. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 02/21/2012.(o0m) (Entered: 02/21/2012)

ORDER as to Joshua A. Rivera-Quinones (22) re 5143 USCA Mandate. In the instant case, the defendant filed a notice of appeal, at docket no. 4129 as to 4106 the judgment  issued against him. On March 27, 2012 at Docket no. 4883 , a MOTION for Retroactive Application of Sentencing Guidelines to Crack Cocaine Offense 18 USC 3582 was filed by the defendant. On June 14, 2012 at Docket no. 5071 Stipulation for Sentencing reduction was filed by the defense and the United States. On June 27, 2012, at Docket no. 5105 an Order reducing sentence, in Re Crack Cocaine Offense pursuant to 18 USC Sec. 3582(c)(2), and it was ordered that the motion filed by the defendant at docket no. 4883 was granted, the defendant's previously imposed sentence of imprisonment of 120 months was reduced to 96 months. On July 2, 2012 at Docket no. 5114 judgment of USCA was issued in which the sentence was vacated, and case was remanded for further proceedings consistent with Dorsey and Hill (Reduction of sentence in Re Crack Cocaine). The Court notes that the Judgment of USCA, Docket no. 5114 , and the Mandate, docket no. 5143 became moot, considering that sentence was reduced consistent with Dorsey and Hill at docket no. 5105 . IT IS SO ORDERED. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 5/17/2013.(o0m) (Entered: 05/20/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Daniel R. Dominguez: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Jose L. Castillo-Torres (104) held on 9/17/2014. Present were: AUSA Victor Acevedo, AFPD Leonardo Aldridge and USPO Orlando Rullan. Defendant present U/C and assisted by the court interpreter. Defendant did not contest the violation. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment were heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution was heard. After hearing the parties, the Court finds that the defendant violated the conditions of supervised release. Therefore, the term of supervised release previously imposed is hereby revoked. IMPR: Eight (8) Months; SRT: Sixty (60) Months. Defendant was advised his right to appeal. ORDER as to Israel Rios-Luciano (19). After analyzing the responses received to the Court's order at Docket No. 5883 , the Court hereby finds good cause and/or excusable neglect to enlarge the time for Petitioner to file his notice of appeal under Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 4(b). Specifically, Petitioner received notice of the Court's denial of his motion for a sentence reduction under 18 U.S.C. §358(c)(2) on December 28, 2015. Petitioner mailed his notice of appeal on January 8, 2016. Because Petitioner mailed his notice of appeal fewer than fourteen days after he received notice of the denial of his motion, the Court finds good cause and/or excusable neglect to enlarge Petitioner's time to file his notice of appeal. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 3/7/2016. (JM) (Entered: 03/07/2016)

ORDER denying 5888 Motion for Leave to Appeal as to Jose L. Velazquez-Maldonado (21). Notwithstanding the merits of Defendant's allegations of good cause or excusable neglect, the Court may not grant the motion as it is devoid of jurisdiction to do so. Federal Rule of Appellate Procedure 4(b) strictly limits the period for which a Court may extend the time for a Defendant to file a notice of appeal to "30 days from the expiration of the time otherwise prescribed by this Rule 4(b)." Under the same rule, Defendant had fourteen (14) days to file his notice of appeal of the Court's December 17, 2015 5888 Order. Thus, Defendant would have a maximum of forty-four (44) days from the date of the Court's order to file the instant notice in compliance with the Rules. However, Plaintiff's motion was signed and dated sixty-six days after the Court's order was entered and was mailed the following day. The Court simply does not have the authority under Rule 4(b) to extend the period to file for Defendant beyond the thirty (30) day threshold, much less by over twenty (20) days. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 3/8/2016. (JM) (Entered: 03/08/2016)

Roig-Vazquez (56); denying 6086 Motion Requesting Order as to Carlos A. Roig- Vazquez (56) Denied. The defendant was to serve 8 years in supervised release of which he has served two and half years. Since he was selling drugs in a protected location warranting a higher period of supervised release. Defendant still has now more than three years left of his statutory term. Defendant may request the same relief when he has served six and a half years. Selling drugs next to a protected locations (schools zones and/ or public housing buildings) constitutes a serious crime with a larger period of time to serve. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 8/23/2017. (bg) (Entered: 08/23/2017)

Present were: AUSA Myriam Fernandez, AFPD Isabelle Oria and USPO Alexandria Oliveras. Defendant present U/C and assisted by the official court interpreter. For this revocation proceedings, defendant will not contest the allegations for the Type C violations. The Court held in abeyance Type A violation and instructed U.S. Probation Officer to file informative motion in ninety (90) days. After having heard the parties, the Court found that defendant violated the conditions of release previously imposed. Therefore, the supervised release term previously imposed was revoked. IMPR: Twelve (12) Months; SRT: Three (3) Years. Defendant was advised his right to appeal. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. (Court Reporter Lisa O'Brien.) Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin: Bail Revocation Hearing as to Obed Alvarado-Merced (60) held on 6/22/2018. Present: AUSA Myriam Fernandez, AFPD Laura Soto, USPO Natalia Feliz. Defendant was U/C, present in court and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defense counsel informed that they reviewed Docket # 6242 and will contest the hearing. Testimony of USPO Natalia Feliz was heard on behalf of the government. Cross-examination by AFPD Soto. After hearing the testimony of the witness and the arguments presented by the parties, the Court found that the defendant violated his conditions of release, but since USPO testified that he has an acceptable place to live, defendant shall be released under the same conditions of release as previously imposed, including EM. USPO to verify if the residence of defendant's sister is acceptable. Another address can also be considered. Defendant will remain detained until address is verified, and confirmation is received that defendant's sister is willing to accept him. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marshal D. Morgan: Preliminary Revocation Hearing as to Edfren Ortiz-Torres (110) held on 8/6/2018. Present were AUSA Myriam Fernandez, AFPD Yasmin Irizarry substituting for AUSA Juan Michelen and USPO Yarixa Vazquez. The defendant was under custody, present in court and assisted by the Court Interpreter. Defense counsel informed the Court that, although the defendant will not contest the alleged Grade C Violations (standard conditions # 3, # 6 & special condition # 3) contained in 6045 Motion filed by USPO Vazquez, he will challenge the allegation that he was involved in new criminal conduct. AUSA Fernandez replied that the Government would not pursue revocation based on the information provided by the P.R. Police Department as described in said motion. As to the 6277 Supplemental Motion filed today, the Government will seek revocation. AFPD Irizarry argued against it. Sidebar held. After having heard the parties, the Court finds that the defendant waived his right to a preliminary hearing as to the Grade C Violations described in motion 6045 therefore probable cause was found. Probable cause was also found as to the violations contained in 6277 supplemental motion given the fact the defendant is charged in Indictment no. 18-469-GAG. The Court noted that the defendant is not accepting the new criminal conduct mentioned in motion 6045 . The case is referred to the Presiding Judge for a Final Revocation Hearing. (Court Reporter DCR Courtroom #1) Hearing set for 9:30 am. Hearing held at 10:35 am. Hearing ended at 11:02 am. Interpreter Annie Navarro. (cmd) (Entered: 08/30/2018)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marshal D. Morgan:Case was called for Preliminary Revocation Hearing re 6414 Motion Notifying SRT Violations as to Manuel De-Jesus-Rios (77) on 12/4/2019, but it was not held. Present: AUSA Marie Christine Amy, AFPD Edwin Mora and USPO Carolina Aparicio. The defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. The parties informed that the defendant's domestic violence case was pending trial in state court. AUSA Amy stated that the Government was ready to proceed with the hearing and would call USPO Aparicio to the stand for her to testify that the defendant was facing felony charges in state court. AFPD Mora stressed the defense's right to cross examine witnesses with personal knowledge of the situation that caused the filing of the domestic violence charges. Defense counsel requested a continuance until after the date of the defendant's next hearing in state court, which was 12/10/2019. The Court  granted the defense's request and continued the hearing. The Government requested reconsideration of the Court's ruling. Reconsideration was denied. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marshal D. Morgan:Preliminary Revocation Hearing re 6414 Motion Notifying SRT Violations as to Manuel De-Jesus-Rios (77) held on 12/18/2019. Present: AUSA Marie Christine Amy, AFPD Edwin Mora and USPO Carolina Aparicio. The defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. The testimony of PRPD Agent Arleen Rosario was heard on behalf of the Government. Direct and cross examinations were conducted. Redirect. AUSA Amy argued for probable cause and for the case to proceed to final revocation hearing. AFPD Mora argued against probable cause, asserting that there had been no reliable testimony to make such finding and questioning the credibility of the victim in this case. Government's rebuttal was heard. After having heard the parties' arguments and the witness' testimony, the Court found probable cause as to the violation included in Docket No. 6414 . The case was referred to U.S. Senior District Judge Daniel R. Dominguez for Final Revocation Hearing. AFPD Mora requested that the defendant remain under the same conditions of release pending the final hearing. The Government objected to the defense's request. The Court ruled that the defendant would remain detained pending the final hearing. Copy of ORDER in Civil Case No. 16-2324 (DRD) denying 5961 Motion to Vacate (§ 2255) as to Richard Medina-Padilla (8). As the Petitioner was sentenced pursuant to the advisory Guidelines regime, and held in Beckles v. United States, 137 S.Ct. 886, 893 (2017) the Supreme Court decided that the Guidelines were not affected by the Johnson v. United States, 576 U.S. 2551, 135 S. Ct. 2551 (2015) decision, the instant Petition is meritless and must be DENIED. Judgment of dismissal is to be entered accordingly. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 6/12/2020. (EA) (Entered: 06/12/2020)

COPY OF JUDGMENT § 2255 in Civil Case No. 16-2324 (DRD) as to Richard Medina-Padilla (8). Pursuant to the Court's Order (Docket. No. 14) denying the Petitioner, Richard Medina Padilla's Pro se Motion to Vacate or Correct Sentence Under 28 U.S.C. § 2255 (Docket. No. 1) because the Petitioner was sentenced pursuant to the advisory Guidelines regime and the Plea Agreement, and because the advisory Guidelines were not affected by the Johnson v. United States, 576 U.S. 2551, 135 S. Ct. 2551 (2015) decision, the Court hereby enters final judgment DISMISSING THE INSTANT CASE WITH PREJUDICE. THIS CASE IS NOW CLOSED FOR ALL ADMINISTRATIVE AND STATISTICAL PURPOSES. IT IS SO ORDERED, ADJUDGED AND DECREED. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 6/12/2020. (EA) (Entered: 06/12/2020)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Bruce J. McGiverin: Preliminary Revocation Hearing as to Geraldo Ortiz-Garcia held on 7/2/2020 via VTC. Case previously set for Removal Hearing in 20-622 (M). Present were AUSA Michele Colon, AFPD Samantha Drake and USPO Linda Perez. Defendant was present and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defendant waived his right to appear physically at the hearing and consented to proceed via VTC. Counsel for the defendant informed that defendant was not disputing the allegations contained in the motion filed by the U.S. Probation Office in the Southern District of Texas and would be waiving his right to a preliminary hearing. The Court found probable cause as to the allegations contained in the motion filed by the probation officer and referred the matter to Judge Daniel R. Dominguez for setting of a Final Revocation Hearing. Government moved for detention pending the final revocation hearing on the basis of risk of flight and danger to the community. Defense counsel argued in favor of release. Statement by USPO Linda Perez heard for the record. Further arguments were made by defense counsel in favor of release. Having heard the parties, the Court granted the Government's motion and ordered the defendant detained pending final revocation. Findings made on the record. (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 11:00. Hearing held at 11:14. Hearing ended at 11:42. Interpreter Olga Uribe. (bgl) Modified on 7/14/2020 as to filng date (gav). (Entered: 07/14/2020)

ORDER as to Hector L. Gonzalez-Vega. Defendant is pending initial appearance for the alleged supervised release violations informed by the USPO in Docket No. 6535. The Federal Public Defender is appointed to represent Defendant for the revocation proceedings. Defendant is not entitled to a preliminary revocation hearing as he is under conditions of release (see F.R.Cr.P. 32.1(b)(1)(A)). Defense counsel is encouraged to arrange a client interview by telephone to consider waiving the initial appearance and get the waiver signed by Defendant to avoid a VTC. The waiver of the initial appearance shall be filed by 8/31/2020 and shall state that, pursuant to FRCP 32.1, Defendant was advised of the right to be present during an initial appearance on revocation proceedings; to have a Magistrate Judge inform him of the alleged violations of supervised release; his right to retain counsel or to request that counsel be appointed; his right to a revocation hearing before the District Judge; and upon the advice of counsel Defendant waives the initial appearance. If the waiver is filed in compliance with the above, the same will be approved and the matter will be referred to the attention of presiding District Judge for a final revocation hearing. In the meantime, Defendant shall continue abiding by all the conditions of his supervised release term. If the waiver is not filed, the Initial Appearance will be set via VTC in due course. Signed by US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive on 08/17/2020. (cvr) (Entered: 08/17/2020)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Daniel R. Dominguez: Final Hearing re  Revocation of Supervised Release as to Geraldo Ortiz-Garcia (30) held on 12/10/2020. Present SAUSA Yanira Colon, AFPD Samantha Drake and USPO Linda Perez. Defendant was under custody and assisted by the court interpreter. The defendant waived his right to appear physically for this proceeding and agreed to proceed with the hearing via VTC. Defense counsel advised that will not contest the allegations form USPO. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Initial Appearance re Revocation of Supervised Release/Show Cause Hearing as to Ramon Gonzalez-Torres (82) held on 3/15/2021 via VTC. Present were AUSA Enrique Silva, AFPD Jessica Earl and USPO Taisa Mojica. Defendant was present under conditions of supervised release and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defendant waived his right to appear physically at the hearing and consented to proceed via VTC. Defendant was advised of the SRT violations as alleged in the motion filed at Docket No. 6648 and as to his right to a final revocation hearing. The FPD's Office has already been appointed to represent the defendant. Pursuant to the Due Process Protections Act, Pub. L. No. 116-182, 134 Stat. 894 (Oct. 21, 2020) and Rule 5(f) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, the United States is reminded of its obligation to disclose in a timely manner all exculpatory evidence to the defendant[s], that is, all evidence that is favorable to the defendant[s] or tends to cast doubt on the United States case, as required by Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963) and its progeny. Failure to comply with this order may result in consequences, including, but not limited to, the reversal of any conviction, the exclusion of evidence, adverse jury instructions, dismissal of charges, contempt proceedings, disciplinary action, and/or sanctions by the Court. Case is referred to Judge Daniel R. Dominguez for setting of a final revocation hearing. As to detention, defense counsel requested that the defendant remain under the same conditions, the Government is not moving for detention. After hearing the parties, the Court ordered the defendant to remain under the same conditions of supervised release and to continue participating in the outpatient program pending the final revocation hearing. (Court Reporter DCR/ZoomGov Recording.) Hearing set for 10:30. Hearing held at 10:35. Hearing ended at 10:47. Interpreter Carlos Ravelo. (rom) (Entered: 03/15/2021)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Giselle Lopez-Soler: Initial Appearance re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Christopher Figueroa- Ortiz (84) held on 4/21/2021 via VTC. Present was AUSA Linet Suarez, AFPD Cherrelle Herbert and USPO Taisa Mojica. Defendant was present under custody and  assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defendant waived his right to appear physically at the hearing and consented to proceed via telephone as he currently is under quarantine, all other participants were present via video. Defendant was advised of the SRT violations as alleged in the motion filed at Docket No. 6636 and as to his right to a preliminary hearing to determine whether the supervised release conditions had been violated. Upon the defendant's request, the Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. Defendant will be represented by the FPD's Office. Pursuant to the Due Process Protections Act, Pub. L. No. 116-182, 134 Stat. 894 (Oct. 21, 2020) and Rule 5(f) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, the United States is reminded of its obligation to disclose in a timely manner all exculpatory evidence to the defendant(s], that is, all evidence that is favorable to the defendant[s] or tends to cast doubt on the United States case, as required by Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963) and its progeny. Failure to comply with this order may result in consequences, including, but not limited to, the reversal of any conviction, the exclusion of evidence, adverse jury instructions, dismissal of charges, contempt proceedings, disciplinary action, and/or sanctions by the Court. As to detention, defense counsel requested conditions of release, the Government did not object but requested stricter conditions. After hearing the parties, the court granted the request and ordered the defendant to be released under the following conditions: the defendant will remain in home incarceration for 14 days starting today. After the completion of the quarantine, the defendant is instructed to visit the USPO's Office for the installation of an EMD, he must also comply with all other standard conditions of supervised release and continue mental treatment as deemed necessary by the USPO. In view that Defendant is under conditions of release, he is not entitled to a preliminary revocation hearing (see F.R.Cr.P. 32.1(b)(1)(A)). This matter is thus referred to the attention of the presiding District Judge for a final revocation hearing. (Court Reporter DCR/ZoomGov Recording.) Hearing set for 01:00. Hearing held at 05:12. Hearing ended at 05:30. Interpreter Olga Uribe. (rom) (Entered: 04/21/2021)

ORDER as to Mariano G. Alfaro-Cintron (102). Defendant is pending initial appearance/show cause hearing for the alleged supervised release violations informed by the USPO in Docket No. 6663. The Federal Public Defender is appointed to represent Defendant for the revocation proceedings. Defendant is not entitled to a preliminary revocation hearing as he is under conditions of release (see F.R.Cr.P. 32.1(b) (1)(A)). Defense counsel is encouraged to arrange a client interview by telephone to consider waiving the initial appearance/show cause hearing get the waiver signed by Defendant to avoid a VTC. The waiver of the initial appearance shall be filed by

21/2021 and shall state that, pursuant to FRCP 32.1, Defendant was advised of the right to be present during an initial appearance on revocation proceedings; to have a Magistrate Judge inform him of the alleged violations of supervised release; his right to retain counsel or to request that counsel be appointed; his right to a revocation hearing before the District Judge; and upon the advice of counsel Defendant waives the initial appearance. If the waiver is filed in compliance with the above, the same will be approved and the matter will be referred to the attention of presiding District Judge for a final revocation hearing. In the meantime, Defendant shall continue abiding by all the conditions of his supervised release term. If the waiver is not filed, the initial appearance/show cause hearing will be promptly set via VTC. The Federal Public Defender is appointed to represent Defendant for the revocation proceedings. Signed by US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive on 05/11/2021. (cvr) (Entered: 05/11/2021)

ORDER denying 6509 Motion to Reduce Sentence as to Isaac Ramos-Toledo (4). Pending before the Court is Isaac R. Toledo's ("Defendant" or "Petitioner") Emergency Motion to Effect Early Release. See Docket No. 6509. In essence, Petitioner requests the Court to release him to home confinement and commute the term of imprisonment to time served. Id. at 5. Petitioner bases his request in attention to the COVID 19 pandemic. Now, the Court notes that Petitioner did not exhaust administrative remedies because he believes that it would have been futile since the Warden of his institution is a "biased decisionmaker subjecting Movant to undue prejudice." Id. at 1. However, Defendant did not provide any details nor evidence to substantiate said contention. Therefore, the Court does not have any reason to excuse Defendant's failure to exhaust administrative remedies. On the other hand, although the Court acknowledges the dangers and challenges that the COVID-19 pandemic has brought upon the Bureau of Prisons ("BOP") and the inmate population, the pandemic -by itself- is not an "extraordinary and compelling" reason to award compassionate release under 18 U.S.C. § 3582. See United States v. Raia, 954 F. 3d 594, 597 (3rd Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 pose in the federal prison system [...] But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOPs statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the viruss spread."). Considering the above, Petitioner's request is hereby DENIED. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 6/24/2021. (DMA) (Entered: 06/24/2021)
